Attention all Raleigh residents who use Town and Country road.  The City has marked this road with paint to layout traffic calming devices that they intend to install.  There are some issues with this design that need to be revealed.  At the intersection of Town and Country a median has been planned that is going to make the right turn off of Millbrook dangerous because of the sharp angle of the turn and because of the natural gas pipes that are above ground at this intersection just off the right on Town and Country.  On the other end of Town and Country there is presently a turn lane for people turning left into the apartments that the city is going to eliminate entirely with a median.  This will, on the first day, cause traffic to back up onto Lead Mine road.  There is also a plan to install an around about where Kingsley intersects Town and Country.  For the folks living on Town and Country who requested this, I predict you will all want this removed within 30 days because of problems you will have accessing your property.  The speed limit is already 30 and the city cannot lower the speed any further due to traffic volume so it seems to me the city is attempting to disregard the law by installing traffic calming devices.  Traffic calming will not decrease the traffic volume on this road because it is a convenient short cut to Millbrook.  If city wants to spend money on this road, it should be spent on resurfacing.
address: Town And Country Raleigh, North Carolina

I know there's work retrofitting SCF into CoR but the new "Categories" are probably a reflection of a sub-optimal approach. If you want SCF to feed directly into CoR departments, you should probably just list the departments and then allow for other categories when users don't know what department to use. Then you'll have a burden to train your users on how to optimize and normalize their category selection. For example, where do zoning problems go? Sign ordinance violations? homeless camps? greenway rapairs? You'll never categorize your audience's thoughts.

The construction worker cranes have destroyed a tree and it sways so bad it could soon fall on the residents and their children from the wind and bad weather. Come tear down this tree today before it falls down on us and send someone to complete the repair and pavement of our street and right away before a resident, child or pedestrian is killed.

Also if pulling out of Sagehurst, one will have to use the middle of the road to stop at the stop sign, thereby, not allowing another car to turn onto the street.  All these people need to do is park the car in their double garage or double driveway, or even on the other side of their driveway.  It would keep their car away from the stop sign.  This issue was posted before.  It seemed the owners complied for a while, but the car is back posing an obstruction.  It seems very unsafe and inconsiderate of them to monopolize the road so close to the stop sign when there are other options.  The picture showing the area does not have the car in it because it is copied from Google Earth.  But the car is in the spot directly over the storm drain.

summary: Traffic Speed Issue Unresolved and Speed Monitoring Sign Removed
description:
Pineview Drive, a neighborhood road, is being used as a through-way which is causing an increased number of accidents and crime in the area.  There is a 90 degree curve on Pineview Drive and drivers DO NOT obey the 15 MPH posted signs.  There have been several accidents at this curve (mailboxes taken out, cars deep in homeowner's yards, etc.).  The issue has been posted numerous times on this site and the issue has not yet been addressed.  I am reposting in the hopes that the City can help protect the neighobors of Pineview Drive.  It is important to note that this road has 0 sidewalks and several children walk this road to Athens High School every day.  Very dangerous!

At one point, the City placed speed monitoring signs at the beginning of the 90 degree curve. These signs, however, were removed within a few days and no other action was taken.  The problem remains.

Previous Post: 

Issue ID:768157 
Viewed:215 times 
Neighborhood:West 
Reported:on 09-29-2013 

The 15-MPH cautionary signs that were put up have done nothing to curb the speeders at the sharp corner on Pineview. 

Could the city please consider one of the following: 
1) Park a police car on the street to ticket speeders, several of us are happy to volunteer our driveways 
2) Setup a permanent sign that flashes the violator's speed next to the recommended speed 
3) Go back to having Pineview Drive as a dead-end where it meets Swift Drive (Note, this eliminates another issue reported presently on the site).

summary: Garbage and Reycle Cans Left in Front Yard within feet of Street Right of Way
description: The business at 301 Dale Street (27605) dumps its garbage, garbage/recycle carts and containers, and yard waste on a separately subdivided adjacent lot at 1220 Pierce Street that is not permitted for off-site storage of garbage/waste from 301 Dale Street.  Further, the garbage/recycle carts are placed in the front yard of the property at 1220 Pierce Street, directly across the street from residential homes, within 15 feet of the right of way, and without any screening which is in violation of City Code.  The foregoing visually detracts from the aesthetic character of the neighborhood (see attached pictures) and in summer months rank and foul odors persist for days and weeks on end making for unsafe environmental conditions.  Accordingly, the City should require that the property and building at 301 Dale Street contain its garbage, recycling, and yard waste to the confines of the property located at 301 Dale Street, move and discontinue placing garbage and/or garbage/recycle containers or carts of any sort on 1220 Pierce Street, and report back to this post that such action - or other appropriate remedial action - has been taken by the City Inspections Department within 10 business days.

description: There are several newly planted trees that are covered with vine overgrowth. Is there still a need to have the green waterbags on the trees?

I live on the 1800 block of White Oak Road in the Five Points neighborhood and we are in desperate need of some form of speed control. 

This block is a one way street. Cars park all up and down both sides for the street. The people that park on the street are both residents of the block, and visitors to the popular area and of the church. When cars are parked on both sides of the road (all the time), it turns into a single lane road. The problem is that cars FLY down this street and there is no room to swerve or avoid anything that may step out into the road or car doors opening. 

Cars fly down this road and if a child or animal were to step out from between parked cars, it would be a tragic and potentially fatal accident. What is worse is even if the driver did see someone stepping out into the road and swerved to miss them, there is nowhere to go to avoid hitting them. Many people walk down this street to get to the 5 points area and all of the restaurants and shops so there is heavy foot traffic.

Cars have clipped my car taking off the side mirror, and you have to take your own life in your hands when getting out of the car that a speeding car does not take off your door. 

This is a narrow street that is occupied by many families with small children and pets. 

It is my understanding that the street was made one way on this block to reduce through traffic but many if not most people using this road do not live on it. This is a straight and down hill street which already makes it easy to gain speed, but people fly going well over 40 MPH and it is dangerous in such a narrow space. Someone is going to get seriously hurt.

I would like to see a speed bump or two put in to slow down the traffic and make it safe for the inhabitants and guests of the neighborhood.
address: 1820 White Oak Road Raleigh, North Carolina

I don't expect anything to come of this because, frankly, the City is thawing out and police have better things to do. But I wanted to report it all the same. At approximately 1:45 today a driver pulled up onto the shoulder of the greenway about 10 feet behind a No Parking sign and let his dog (off-leash) out of the car. The dog ran across the foot bridge toward the playground (this is at the Beaverdam Greenway, near Devonshire). I called out to him that I thought that was a no parking zone and he said,"Nope. It stops right there," and pointed to the sign. I told him he was tearing up the greenway, but he seemed not to care.

I kept walking, then decided to turn around and get a picture of his plate. I could see him in the distance, standing beside his car, looking at me, which made me wonder if he was watching me all along. Given the recent news reports over road rage and parking spaces, I thought it might be best to just turn around and go home. It's not worth it. And if you call dispatch, they ask your name, which I don't feel comfortable giving.

description:
Driving down Currituck road yesterday I noticed road markings for what appears to be traffic calming devices.  What is strikingly obvious to me is that this is about to become the most dangerous road in North Hills.  Placing obstacles in the road, especially on a hill, is going to cost someone their life.  Similar traffic calming devices are in place on Reedy Creek road just off of Edwards Mill road.  Where the center islands exists, drivers are running off the road and into the grass.  The ruts are clearly visible.
The petition process for this, as with the petitions for other traffic calming projects, was not done in the best interest of the citizens in the neighborhoods.  The petition signatures have been suspect, people on adjoining streets were not notified of the meetings, and there is no record of signatures of people opposed to the project.  Further, there is no evidence of a speeding problem.  The city placed a counter on Currituck for a 24 hour period and determined from that a speeding problem existed.  The real issue all over Raleigh is not speeding, but rather increased traffic because of the growth of the city.  One of the problems with forcing people to drive slower is it gives them more opportunity to send text messages or check email.  Both are much more dangerous than driving five miles per hour over the speed limit.
The city has hired people to run this traffic calming program and they have to find something to do and this is the result.  I am very annoyed in the continued waste of my tax dollars on this program.  I am also frustrated to no end that the city council refuses to acknowledge the opposition to this program.

description: Heading North on Atlantic Ave, there is a well marked left-turn only lane for traffic to turn left at the light onto Wolfpack Lane - this is the way I get to work. There is a person who repeatedly is heading South (opposite the direction of what I'm going) on Atlantic Ave, about 8:00 am - 8:15 am Monday - Friday, who goes straight through the intersection and gets into MY turn lane described above so they can illegally turn left into the parking deck which is clearly marked for no entry from that direction.  This person makes it dangerous or impossible for me to get into my left-turn only lane and approach my traffic light.  I assume this person doesn't want to wait in one of their own two left-turn only lanes for traffic heading South on Atlantic Ave to turn left onto Highwoods Blvd so they can go the way they're supposed to and get to parking deck, but this is dangerous and a blatant disregard of driving rules and I would like to see this person stop doing this before somebody gets hurt.

summary: Driver Inattention has caused many to run red lights at intersection
description:
The traffic signal is not malfunctioning, but I have a safety concern. I see at least 3 to 4 drivers in a 5 day period every week run the red light at the intersection at Edwards Mill Rd and the on ramp to Wade Avenue. 

The lights turn green at different times and due to driver inattention drivers are running the red lights. There have been many near miss accidents at these intersections. 

For example, if you are heading north on Edwards Mill and you are at the stop light at Edwards Mill and East Wade Avenue, the light at the next intersection at West Wade Avenue will turn green. If the drivers are not paying attention they will run the red light not realizing their light has remained red. This does allow for better traffic flow, but I see this happen during rush hour traffic and I am concerned about safety. In the past 2 days I have seen 3 cars run the red light and they had to swerve to miss a car entering Edwards Mill from Wade Avenue.
address: Edwards Mill Road Raleigh, North Carolina

I also noticed that the signal for making a left going west off of hillsborough does not have the same issue and is a protected left on green light and doesn't seem to be causing any issues. This signal is no more then a 100 feet from the other signal in question.

Making this a flashing yellow light vs. a solid red should be sufficient. It is not that significant of an unprotected left turn since the visibility is so good. I have experienced a lot more left turns where it is worse than this one - for example, turning onto dilliard drive or athens drive off of tryon - both use flashing yellow lights to keep the traffic flowing.

There is a severe drainage issue in the 1800 block of White Oak Road. The issue really starts between 1818 and 1820 white oak road. At this point there is a massive drainage line that runs from Hayes Barton Baptist Church's parking lot and dumps onto the sidewalk and road. It washes out anything on the curb like trashcans or yard waste. The water flows so intensely that trashcans are often washed down the street and slam into cars parked. The sidewalk becomes completely washed away.

it does not take much water at all to result in a river running down the right side of the street/sidewalk. This issue needs to be addressed. 

The issue is causing there to be erosion on my retaining wall that hold my property up. 

I am attaching pictures of the waterfall that dumps into the road from the church even when it is barely raining. I have dozens more of the river that flows downstream if you would like.

description: This concerns the sidewalk on the west side of St. Mary's Street between College Place and Calvin (the Wiley elementary school frontage.) The "planting strip" between the sidewalk and the back of curb is only about 8-10 inches wide. Storm drainage along this portion of the street is sheet flow on the surface, and the water has washed all the dirt out of the planting strip making it a trip hazard. The PTA has discussed the problem and we do not think that we would be able to plant in the strip without the storm water washing away our efforts. A small portion of the strip has been filled in with concrete (about 10 feet south and 40 feet north of W. Jones street) but we don't know when this was done or by whom. This makes the sidewalk feel safer, and eliminates the trip hazard. Would it be possible for the City to fill in the rest of the planting strip between College Place and Calvin with concrete?

Like many, Glenwood is my daily commute to work. I like to set my cruise control to just under (2-3mph) of the posted speed limit (45mph then 35mph toward into the city) and I am amazed at how much I am passed by drivers going well above the speed limit, including non-emergency police officers, city public works vehicles, and CAT buses. This morning I left later than usual and reduced my speed to 25mph for the school zone around 5 points and I was being honked at and flipped off by drivers passing me. Is it possible to either raise the speed limit or implement more speed control/advisory in this area? Radar speed signs with visible speeds of cars could be nice, or even more police presence and speed traps. I've seen one or two near misses along this road with people rushing through and not paying attention, and the roads are quite narrow in parts as it is. God bless. x

description: People turning left have two choices: left lane or right lane. The right lane ends almost immediately into a parking lot, so people end up doing last minute lane shifts. Others use that right-hand lane to pass the left-hand lane traffic and then try to squeeze in. In either case, people merging from that right-hand lane into the left-hand lane slow down the traffic, causing people at the end of the line to miss the light. From the patterns I have observed in the mornings, it would appear that blocking off one of the turn lanes at this intersection would make traffic flow much more efficiently. Once people turn left onto women's club Drive, they can choose which lane to be in at that time. Most people, anyway, would choose to keep left and follow women's club Drive rather than turn into the parking lot. Is this something that can be investigated? I think it would help to alleviate the complaints of people missing the light.

description: Sounds like a crosswalk out of sync and pinging constantly at Cameron Village.

Saturday morning after 9:30 AM on Oct. 18th walking on Fayetteville Street it was sad to encounter over ten spots--between Davie Street and Morgan Street that featured one or more of the following: vomit, broken beer bottles, and empty unbroken beer bottles. 

The Street Cleaners in the red shirts were doing a fine job getting it all tidied up for another day in Raleigh--these folks are to be commended for cleaning up the disgusting leavings generated by nightlife that needs to be more carefully regulated by the Raleigh City Council, the Downtown Raleigh Alliance, and the Raleigh Police. 

The problem is not the people cleaning the streets. The problem are city leaders who put up with allowing Fayetteville Street to become such a cesspool of side effects.

The mess being cleaned up are the side effects of too many clubs in too small an area over-serving people to the point where vomit and broken bottles are rather common in the morning...as is the crazy amount of noise late at night which many of us do not even bother reporting any longer due to ineffective responses. 

Cleaning up the mess is appreciated
--we salute you red shirted street cleaners. 

We don't appreciate public officials who let the root causes which produce this mess continue.

Raleigh--let's grow up and get our laws enforced. Let's not wake up in a few years with an unattractive downtown just because city leaders allowed way to many bars and clubs and then refused to enforce the law.

description: Need to update the sensor cycle on the Dan Allen drive and Western Boulevard light. During evening rush hour (5pm-5:30pm), the green light lasts a very long time for traffic coming off of Dan Allen on campus - so long that no cars are left on Dan Allen since traffic there is lighter, relatively. Unfortunately, the domino effect of this is that traffic completely backs up down Western Boulevard to the light at the intersection of Western and Avent Ferry/Morrill Drive. So the issue is that left turners from Avent Ferry pull out into the intersection, have nowhere to go because the light at Dan Allen is red for Western Blvd for so long, and those left turners completely block the intersection for a whole cycle of green lights from the Morrill Drive traffic exiting NC State. For the third day in a row now, I have seen this traffic pattern completely jam up the intersection so that no one or only one or two cars can exit Morrill drive. It never used to do this, so I'm wondering if some cycling between the Dan Allen light and the Avent Ferry light has recently been adjusted, causing the new conflict. Someone should set up a camera to record the jam that reoccurs, or station a police officer to ticket the whole lines of left turners who fill and block the intersection for everyone else - illegally.

summary: Jenny Law and the RPD Drag Race Squad, Part Deux
description:
Back on Feb 17th, I filed an issue ( http://seeclickfix.com/issues/926038 ) and it was politely closed and swept under the rug by one Capt RL Munn RPD as being a necessity to insure public safety.

With all due respect, I call BS. 

Here it is almost 2am on a work night, and there's a party going on in front of my house! With cops! In cars! Flying up and down the road. Screeching tires! Flashing lights! Whooping and hollering (ok, maybe not so much whooping and hollering but my point is)

ITS. TWO. AM. ON. A. WORK. NIGHT. PEOPLE!!! I cant sleep. I mean, I *could* sleep but.... I go to sleep and the Indy 500 starts in my front yard. As I pointed out to the very nice female officer whom I approached whilst seated beside Six Forks Rd, ITS TWO AM ON A WORK NIGHT, can't you move your operation 100 yards up the road to the corner of Cranbrook? There's a wider spot in the road! You can get people on radar quicker! You can see further up the road! There are no houses near there were you are going to ADVERSELY AFFECT SOMEONES SLEEP!! Her curt and polite answer was "Oh, well we like this spot, it's our favorite, we've always used it" Really? I mean, hold on. REALLY?
You wanna catch speeders you say, Capt RL Munn? Well then why don't you get your race team out here each and every morning from 7am to, oh, 9am and run a Florida Speed Trap with an officer on the side of the road running radar and 10 cars behind him, primed and ready to pounce. Lets never mind the fact that it'll snarl traffic so severely someone might actually complain, but you say basically I will be woken (or is that awoke?) each and every night your officers so dictate that they park in their "favorite spot" because you know, its for the 'greater good'. If the 'greater good' is getting speeders to slow down as the are approaching Carroll Middle School (as a member of the Capital Police pointed out to me) then shouldn't your teams be out en force at an later hour instead of 2am?

My eyes are burning. I haven't any sleep, and I have to be up and out the door in T-minus 5 hrs to go to work.  Thank you Raleigh Police Department, it's highly appreciated. Good night. Or good morning or what the heck ever.
address: 5140-5148 Six Forks Road Raleigh, North Carolina

description:
PLEASE re-open my earlier concern about the bus stop in front of the east facade of 401 Oberlin Road.  This morning, coach 1284, Outbound 12 Method, leaving Moore Square Station *DID* board passengers at the shelter located as described above.  *HOWEVER*, I could not see that there was any sign indicating that this was a CAT bus stop.  AND, MOREOVER, the safety concern I alluded to in my earlier inquiry has not been alleviated.  Specifically, the stop located about 8-9 meters North of the intersection of Oberlin and Stafford has not been moved to the site east of 401 Oberlin with passenger amenities.  The stop at 401 Oberlin Road appears to be without sign, which will discourage new riders from choosing this as an initial point of engagement with the CAT system and -- arguably -- causes confusion to existing riders as to whether passenger amenities are available to all patrons or -- at certain locales -- only to an exclusive group of invitees.  

The exiting stop, 8-9 meters north of the intersection of Oberlin and Stafford is a pedestrian death waiting to happen.

I sincerely invite you to ask the driver of coach 1284, Outbound 12 Method about the measures she TRIED to take to warn a passenger who had just disembarked that a vehicle was turning west onto Stafford from the Southbound center lane of Oberlin in front of the coach and wholly without regard to pedestrian traffic crossing Stafford.

This is NOT an irregular occurrence and – in fact – will become less infrequent as the 401 building becomes more completely occupied.

I appreciate that the current stop on Oberlin is convenient for workers and patrons (including many seniors) wishing to visit the McDonald's on Oberlin Road and Cameron, but – on balance – I think the physical welfare and even lives of the few folks who disembark and trod south on the Oberlin sidewalk trumps the imposition of a few extra steps to reach the workplace or free coffee.

summary: Urgent and 3rd request : ZERO visibility due to a hedge on Wake Forest / Poplar.  Other Issues not noted above
description:
This is an URGENT safety issue.  We need a permanent and immediate solution to the hedge located on a property on Wake Forest road (about 1/2 block up, on the left as you face north) near the intersection of Poplar Street.. This hedge COMPLETELY blocks visibility for cars on Poplar that are trying to turn onto Wake Forest Road in either direction. Many, if not most,  residents of Mordecai, Pilot Mill and Capitol Park use Poplar to get onto Wake Forest Road every day, several times a day and each time, it is a roll of the dice if a car coming down WF toward downtown will hit you.   This is my third time reporting this.  It was addressed once, and the hegde was trimmed back a little but it  quickly grows back.  Please have the entire hedge removed before someone gets very hurt.   We look forward to your prompt reply. 

Original report of the issue: There are large shrubs on the sidewalk that severely block visibility for drivers trying to turn left (North Bound) onto Wake Forest Road from Poplar Street. It is extremely dangerous; you have to pull out into Wake Forest Rd. in order to see if traffic is coming. This has been a problem for years and hope to see this fixed.

summary: Traffic Hazard on Jones Franklin Rd at Wayne St
description:
Every Saturday, beginning in the AM a group of protesters are around the corner from Jones Franklin Rd & Wayne St. The group will be anywhere of a handful of people to around 50 or more. They park their cars along Wayne St and Jones Franklin Rd. 
Jones Franklin Rd already has enough traffic & hazards on its own. I live down Wayne St and even on a good day or good time struggle with traffic issues on Jones Franklin. There are usually long lines of traffic coming from both ways with no break in traffic. Drivers are not paying attention and sometimes people have to pull out into traffic just to get out of driveways. When a huge distraction is thrown in, it makes the problem worse.
It makes it almost impossible for anyone to turn in or out of Wayne St not only due to traffic, but your line of sight is blocked by cars and people. Traffic will be backed up on both streets and people are slamming on brakes and stopping in the middle of the road to look at all the people. Its also impossible for vehicles to enter & exit Wayne st with the cars parked along both sides of the streets.

Jones Franklin Rd desperately needs improvement and also needs police presence to help with aggressive and speeding drivers. I have been ran off the road and rear ended twice on Jones Franklin Rd., i have lived here for 5 months! 
This road is a disaster! Please help

I assume the wrong sign was just put up with the traffic light.  There seems to always be more traffic looking to turn left onto falls than to turn right.

I have personally had to wait multiple light cycles to turn left after this sign change.

Suggestion is to add back the left or right turn sign for the middle lane.

summary: Crosswalks and Sidewalks to Keep Students Safe
description: The intersection of Dixie Forest Rd., Litchford Rd., Old Wake Forest Rd., and Atlantic Ave is perpetually busy with multiple lanes of 45 mph traffic. At this intersection is the new and hugely popular Sheetz gas station, Han-Dee Hugo's convenience store, and a soon-to-open Waffle House. The intersection is less than 100 yards from Millbrook High School. Several affordable apartment communities are also within walking distance of this popular intersection. On a daily basis, I see pedestrians of all ages hazardously crossing from one corner to another to access the aforementioned places. Most prominently, I see adolescents crossing these intersections coming from the direction of MHS and River Birch apartments. Many of these pedestrians belong to minority racial groups. There are no crosswalks at these intersections. A few years ago, a high school student was hit by a car while trying to cross this intersection. As business continues to develop and students, workers, and community members continue to use these pathways, it is imperative that they are provided with crosswalks and sidewalks to safely cross streets.
address: 2321-2399 Dixie Forest Road Raleigh, North Carolina

This morning I caught them with an extension chord in my front outlet into their front window. I have contacted RPD and the city numerous times and nothing gets done . Myself and  the residents of Bison hill town homes would like to see something done at 3801 Bison Hill Lane as they now have no electric and there are infants and young children in the home.

description:
A small portion of Lorimer Rd was closed last Thurs. (not in front of any houses) so the recycling truck completely skipped the section between Onslow Rd and Garland Dr.  By Monday night, still no pickup, so I submitted a pickup request online.

Problem 1: The online form does not have a space for adding free text or noting that more houses besides my own were not serviced.
Problem 2: A truck came this morning and got my recycle, but did not get the neighbors!  So the driver came out there just to get mine, and did not have the sense to think that maybe all the other blue containers along the street also need emptying.
Problem 3: The driver who emptied my container left it out in the street.  He could have taken three more steps and gotten it out of the street, but instead he left a safety hazard.

Not impressed.

Restrooms at Shelly Lake are in poor condition, serious need of renovation.   In addition, most of the time they are not clean.  Not sure why Shelly Lake is being neglected with the number of visitors and special events held there.

summary: Signals / Signs - People Still Feeding Birds!
description: Need more signs about not feeding the birds. At least two groups feeding birds on Sunday morning.   It would also be helpful if signs were more visible at either end of the bridge.

It is a death trap leaving Londonderry Subdivision (Waterside Dr) trying to get onto Millbrook Rd. There are trees obstructing views on either side and a dangerous curve. Cars speed around that curve and you can't see them so you're basically playing Russian roulette everyday. City of Raleigh was notified a couple of years ago, their response: it's private property.

Yesterday new traffic lights were activated at Leesville Rd and Farless Rd at Sycamore Creek Elementary School.  This morning, the left turn arrow for traffic egressing the SCES parking lot was not working.  The left turn arrow stayed red through every light cycle.  Previously, it was green once per cycle long enough for 4-5 cars to exit the parking lot making the left turn.  Please fix the new lights so traffic can safely get out of the school parking lot.  Thank you.

summary: No safe way for cars/pedestrains to proceed through the intersection
description: The convergence of Poplar St, Mordecai Dr and Courtland Dr causes a 5 point intersection. Drivers coming north on Mordecai Dr appear to have the "right of way", but they cannot safely see around the corner to turn left onto Courtland Dr., as they cannot see oncoming traffic yet are forced to yield on the left turn.  Traffic on Poplar St cannot see well enough around the corner, yet they have to yield to traffic coming north on Mordecai Dr.  Pedestrians added into the mix (without any crosswalks) are also unable to see traffic coming from various directions.  Make this a 5 way stop before somebody gets killed, please.

description: There should be a "No left Turn"  from Brookside into Conn Elementary during carpool hours.  Having cars come  from the left and then cars lined up on Brookside trying to make a right into Conn, then all the cars traveling through.  Not too mention all the excited kids running around.  It is a crazy mess.  I think that one small change would help.  Then you would have ALL the cars lined up along Brookside making a right, the cars traveling through, would not have to sit through multiple cycles while a car trying to make the left gets caught in the middle of the street. Kids would have an easier path with the crossing guard instead of having to walk in and out of cars.  Just during carpool time so it would not be a big change for folks all the time.  Ligon has done something similar and that has made things run so much smoother.

summary: Cedar tree blocking pedestrian's view at crossing
description: There's a pedestrian crosswalk in the median between the church at 2723 Clark Ave. and their parking lot.  Immediately to the right (east) of that crosswalk, there's a large cedar tree that blocks pedestrians' view of oncoming traffic.  It's just a matter of time before someone steps out in front of an oncoming car that was blocked by the tree.  The city recently removed a dead crepe myrtle to the left (west) of that crosswalk.  Could the city transplant the beautiful cedar tree from its current location to the former location of the crepe myrtle?  In any case, the cedar tree needs to be removed to prevent a tragedy.

description: Another close call. Drivers are routinely switching lanes inside of the intersection at this dangerous, confusing intersection.   This issue had been submitted earlier.  Lanes do not line up as one moves through the intersection and some drivers mistakenly believe they can choose any of the four lanes south of the intersection regardless of the lane they are in when entering the intersection from the north (Lead Mine Rd).  There are hash marks leading drivers through, but these are ignored. Either because drivers cannot see the faded marks or they do not understand what is going on.  This is causing other drivers to swerve out of the way of these lane changing drivers. Please do something to make this intersection safer by repainting the marks, adding reflectors/bollards and/or additional signage to instruct drivers how to move safely through the intersection.
address: 4350-4398 Lead Mine Road Raleigh, NC 27612, USA

description: Many trucks (dumptrucks and 18-wheelers, mostly) mistakenly turn left off S. Wilmington St. onto Layden St. into Hertford Village. Traffic going straight through in both directions. Traffic turning right into the school in the very short turning lane. The three straight lanes flow into four lanes after the signal light at North Hills Dr. There are hash lines painted in the intersection indicating the two left straight lanes are to flow directly into the two left turning lanes to go to the beltline or to go east on Glenwood Ave. that leaves the right lane from Lead Mine to go into the either of the two right lanes going straight onto Blue Ridge Rd. or to turn right on Glenwood. 

Those hash marks in the intersection of Lead Mine and North Hills Dr. are so faded, that it is difficult for drivers to know which lane they should remain in when moving through the intersection. There are many close calls between the drivers moving over when they are in the middle straight lane and leave the turning lane to go straight across Glenwood.

This beautiful area that is being neglected is losing it's natural beauty and as a result the wildlife (herons, egrets, hawks, owls, woodpeckers) is suffering. description: This property is severly overgrown in the back yard.  I understand that if the city can't see it from the street they can't do anything but you CAN see this from the street.  There are weeds and saplings over the six foot privacy fence.  There is poison ivy growing up the trees and through the fence into neighboring yards.  There are rodents running throught the yard.  There is standing water with mosquitoes breeding.  There are wild animals pushing through the fence into neighboring yards.  This property is decreasing the property values of the homes around or near it.  This property has been reported at least three times that I am aware of.  It was reported last year as well.  The city came out last year and the owner mowed down the weeds and saplings leaving a square in the middle of the yard untouched.  That is not acceptable.  The untouched section was still a breeding ground for voles, mice, snakes and mosquitoes.  The yards around this property are unusable due to the poison ivy growing through, the mosquitoes and the rodents running.  Children are unable to play in the neighboring yards because of the risk of poison and the possiblity of snakes, rodents etc.  Pets are unable to be left in neighboring yards due to the risk of hearworm carrying mosquitoes.

This email thread represents a situation in The Fields Development at 3404 Neptune Drive.  I, as the President of The Fields HOA Board of Directors, have worked with the City of Raleigh Inspections Office for more than a year to bring this issue to a resolution.  To the best of my knowledge, the homeowner has not pulled the appropriate permits for the construction of a retaining wall.  According to the below email string, the retaining wall is not acceptable to the City of Raleigh.  I understand that all folks in government have limits to their authority.  However, I’d like to know what action will be taken by the City of Raleigh to ensure that this retaining wall is correct in its design and construction.  Please advise.  Thank you.

Perry F. Stewart
President, The Fields HOA BOD
H/O 3209 Planet Drive
Raleigh NC 27604

I have no authority to do anything else.  For anything else to occur is outside the authority I am granted here at the City of Raleigh.  
Don Harris
City of Raleigh 
Building Inspector III
8320 Litchford Rd., Suite 130
PO Box 590
Raleigh, NC 27602-0590
Cell # (919) 278-6150
Email don.harris@raleighnc.gov
Website: www.raleighnc.gov

description: This has bothered me all weekend so I decided to report this.  On Friday, the CAT bus driver let other passengers board from NC State by only swiping their GoPass. Well I have cancer and am going through treatment and that's why I don't have hair on my head like my ID shows.  If you're going to have a policy to make NC State employees show their ID you should be consistent, make all show their ID, not just those with a lighter tone of skin.

description: On Friday 1st August I was first on the scene at an accident which involved a driver losing vehicle control and crashing into cypress trees just beyond the intersection of Wild Dunes Drive and Royal Troon Drive in the Hedingham subdiivision. If the cyprees trees(planted by the property owner) had not been there the vehicle would have crashed into a house and caused serious damage to both house and vehicle not to mention possible loss of life. Wild Dunes Drive is used by drivers as a shortcut to using Southall to Eagle Trace. There have been several incidents at this intersection since 'traffic calming' was instituted on Eagle Trace. The only way to slow traffic on Wild Dunes Drive is to place speed bumps at strategic locations, which will prevent speeding and reckless driving. Wild Dunes is popular for pedestrians and is not meant to be a 'thruway' There is no sidewalk and a blind corner which makes entry into Wild Dunes Drive from Long Point and Grand Cypress a risky process.
address: Wild Dunes Drive Raleigh, North Carolina

This past Tuesday, Aug 12th, the garbage truck that services my neighborhood left thick trails of oil on our streets. This wasn't a simple drip here and there, this was a steady stream of fluid. Surely the truck lost a substantial amount if oil; whether it be motor oil or hydraulic fluid. You can follow these oil trails throughout the Sawmill Rd area, tracing the truck's route. The stains are the heaviest in my immediate area [Hemlock Ct].

This is not only an eye sore, but also an environmental concern. There was rain Tuesday evening which in turn washed the standing oil into the surrounding drains. 

Myself and my neighbors hope that the department for truck maintenance is alerted of the leaking truck and it is repaired immediately. No doubt this truck is driving on other routes in Raleigh. Moreover, we would like our street treated in an environmentally safe way so that the oil is pulled up from the asphalt.

Thank you,

Neighbors of Hemlock Ct

summary: Parks / Greenways "Yield to Pedestrian Sign Not Present"
description:
This road has constant traffic during peak traffic times, which makes it unsafe to cross to get to the Greenway trail.  All the other crosswalks to Greenways in the area have a "State Law, Yield to Pedestrians" sign, which is not present at this updated crosswalk.  

I have almost been hit a few times, or must stand for awhile before cars will stop to let me walk.  In addition, there are many times that the cars do not even slow down once I am in the cross walk.  I use this crosswalk daily, and should not be fearful to use it to get to Greenway access.  I see teens trying to cross here to get to school as well.  Please add a sign at the very least, or make the cross walk more visible.  The bus stop makes it less likely for drivers to see pedestrians as well.

I'd like to reopen issue #1122929.  The parking problem has not been fully addressed.  School began today and I again observed buses not being able to pull up in front of the school due to cars parked in the way.  I'm including 2 pictures.  One shows 1 bus in front of the school and a line of parked cars, which prevented the second bus from pulling up in front of the school.  The second picture shows the second bus.  It is to the east of Swain St., one block away from the school.  This can't be ideal for student safety.  Additionally, there is a city bus stop on this block (E. Hargett between Swain and Monie).  The parked cars prevent the city bus from pulling up to the bus stop.  Finally, my neighbors and I have difficulty pulling out of our neighborhood (Monie Ln.), because we cannot see around the parked cars.  Today this block of Hargett St was only about half full of parked cars.  Many days the entire block is full of parked cars.  On those days, the buses can't get near the school.  Please consider making the entire block "no parking" - 500 E. Hargett St.

description:
The owners moved out a few months ago and their son is crashing here now but not maintaining the property at all. RPD advised to report to SeeClickFix the conditions to initiate a nuisance case against the property.

This morning RPD and animal control removed an emaciated and abused dog from the property. She was starved for at least two months according to Animal Control. Criminal abuse charges are now pending against the son. The windows were open and the smell of cat feces was in the air. There is still at least one cat inside the sparsely furnished home. 

The grass is knee high and gone to seed. There are large broken limbs littered through the yard. 

An inoperable vehicle with expired tags is in the driveway with rusting tools, trash and water filled boxes scattered throughout the driveway. 

The back porch door is busted and unsecured. This allowed for the neglected dog to access the back porch.

summary: Whitaker Mill Road In Even Worse Shape
description: Over a week and a half ago the top layer of asphalt was shaved off in preparation for resurfacing that was to take place in later June or early July.   This road is in terrible condition.  In addition to the potholes and general rough texture there are multiple manhole-type covers and other fixtures that have raised asphalt surrounding them that are not painted or marked and are very hard to see at night.  This seems dangerous for a motorcyle, moped, or cars with lower profile tires.  It is furstrating that, again, there seems to be poor coordination between the time the road was prepped for resurfacing and the actual resurfacing.  There just doesnt seem to be anyting being done to improve the road condition on a day to day basis.  The entire project on this road has been mishandled and the residents in the neighborhood along this road, who pay substantial property taxes, have been poorly served during the duration of this debacle.   The City Council should take notice.  Im posting this hoping someone can give us an update of what is holding up progress on the resurfacing.
address: 117 East Whitaker Mill Road Raleigh, North Carolina

description:
Running red lights is ridiculously rampant.  It happens every day at every light.  I am requesting that enforcement be made more of a priority.  Specifically, I would request that an UNMARKED police vehicle be posted at the Millbrook x Glenwood intersection.  There are 3 left turn lanes and multiple vehicles blow through the red long after it turns red daily, especially at rush hour.

I reported this before and a marked police vehicle was sent, so of course more people played by the rules.   Until the police car was gone.  

It's so bad that even for drivers on the other side of the street, you can to wait about 10 seconds after the light is green to start going (in the straight lane on Millbrook) because so many cars are just blatantly running the red and turning left on red anyway.  It is unsafe.
address: 3497-3499 West Millbrook Road Raleigh, North Carolina

description: There has been a recent change to the traffic light pattern at Macon Pond Rd and Blue Ridge Rd.   This is not a good change during the morning commute.  What typically takes 7 minutes to get from Glenwood Ave to Lake Boone Trail using Duraleigh/Blue Ridge now takes 15 minutes.  The light isn't staying green long enough for the traffic coming on Duraleigh from Edwards Mill to make it through both the Blue Ridge and Macon Pond lights.  It's making traffic back up past Edwards Mill.   When it finally does turn green, the traffic coming from Blue Ridge at Crabtree all get to go through.   The traffic coming from Edwards Mill is stuck sitting at the Blue Ridge/Duraleigh light and then the Macon Pond light.   It's making traffic flow during the morning commute much more congested.
address: Macon Pond Rd At Blue Ridge Rd Raleigh, North Carolina

Non-Erodible Surfaces Required for Residential Front-Yard Parking

The City of Raleigh requires that driveways and parking within the front yard of single family detached dwellings be constructed of non-erodible surfaces such as asphalt, concrete or pavers, or four inches of gravel with permanent borders.  Otherwise, parking is restricted to single-file parking in front of the driveway cut.

description: The intersection of Trailwood Dr and Lineberry has one of the most sensitive light changes.  While traveling on Trailwood, you're lucky to have the light stay green for more than 10 seconds.  If anyone at all is coming from Lineberry or towards Wolftech the light will begin to change before the car even reaches the intersection.  And if someone is simply turning right the light changes but the car has already turned and drove off.  More times than not the light just changes all of a sudden and no one is even there.  The intersection changes too frequently and might as well be a four way stop with how often it turns red.  Travel down the road a couple times of a day and its easy to see it.

summary: Last week's recycling not picked up
description: Called in Friday that my and my neighbor's recycling was missed.  No big deal.  Neighbor called again today, and he was told that they don't do pickups on Monday.  Again, no big deal.  Yet over lunch, somehow their recycling was retrieved.  Mine, 10 yards away, remains full.  Come on, guys?   I hate that you missed our houses.  Mistakes happen.  But when you come and empty my bin, please don't toss is haphazardly into the street like it's been hit by a car (because that's what happened to my neighbor today).  We respect you (neighbors put coolers of iced water bottles out in hot days!), so please return it to us.

Please take a look at this picture of 3304 Planet Drive, a long term vacant house in The Fields development that has become quite an eyesore.

Please note condition of house – to include vines growing up the front of the house along a window frame, facia board coverings peeled back exposing wood to the elements, and a hanging shutter.

Our HOA professional management company, HRW, Inc. has sent letters to BB&T about home maintenance.  This house is going downhill fast and needs to be addressed by the owners.  

This home is currently owned by BB&T.  The address on file for BB&T is 301 College St., Greenville, SC 29601-2014.  HRW has received no response from them to date regarding requests for corrective action.

As HOA Board President, I try and work toward maintaining and enhancing the value of homes in our development -- both for homeowners and for the community at large.  A rundown home such as this erodes homeowners' home values and contributes to eventual decline in the entire development.

Please weigh in on this matter with the enforcement capacity of the City of Raleigh to get this home cleaned up.

Thanks!

Perry Stewart
